textContent:
KYIV, Ukraine — When a missile slammed into an apartment block on the north side of the Ukrainian capital just after dawn on Monday, many residents were fast asleep.

They had become accustomed to the sounds of shelling after more than two weeks of Russian bombardment, but they never thought their building would be hit.

“We do not have a military target near us,” said Yuriy Yurchik, 30. “We did not think we ourselves would be a target.”

Kyiv,  only weeks ago a vibrant and serene city of 2.8 million people looking toward the future, is now buffeted by the terror of war. Missile strikes have intensified in recent days as Russia’s military offensive presses closer to the heart of the government.

Mr. Yurchik was awoken by a white light, he said. The room filled with an orange glow, and then a loud explosion rocked the building and blew in the windows.

“I looked out and saw the left part of the building was burning,” he said. “On the ground people were running and screaming.”

Two people were killed and nine wounded in the strike, which occurred in Obolon district in the northern part of Kyiv. The Ukrainian authorities evacuated 70 people from the building to a nearby kindergarten.
